awd_titl_txt: UNS:  Formation and Toxicity of Disinfection Byproducts in Desalinated Waters
awd_abstract_narration:
1511051
Amy

Currently, seawater reverse osmosis is the most commonly used desalination technology. Specifically, the blending of reverse osmosis desalinated water with single or multiple treated fresh waters drawn from other sources is a low-cost method to meet the demands of drinking water and to increase the concentration of some desired ions. Therefore, the objective of this project is to conduct a comprehensive and systematic study to examine the formation and speciation of reaction byproducts of disinfection and the toxicity changes of seawater reverse osmosis desalinated waters as a consequence of blending.

This is the first comprehensive research that combines a disinfection byproduct study on the formation, speciation, and factors affecting bromide/iodide incorporation with a toxicology study to determine possible toxicities on mammalian cells. In this study, the PIs propose to investigate: 1) the formation and speciation of brominated/iodinated disinfection byproducts in the presence of hydrophilic organic matter (e.g., algal organic matter, wastewater effluent organic matter, natural organic matter) of different origins in treated waters that are likely to be used for blending with seawater reverse osmosis permeate, 2) the effects of pH and temperature on the formation and speciation of brominated/iodinated disinfection byproducts, 3) the change in mammalian cell cytotoxicity and genotoxicity of waters from blending, and 4) the ability of total organic halide species and/or other individual brominated/iodinated disinfection byproducts to predict the cytotoxicity and genotoxicity of the blended waters based on a multiple regression. The project will be conducted in two phases: Phase 1, which entails a disinfection byproduct study on the formation, speciation, and factors affecting bromide/iodide incorporation under various mixing scenarios and using chlorine and chloramine for post-disinfection (i and ii); and Phase 2, which entails a toxicity study on mammalian cell cytotoxicity and genotoxicity of waters from blending and multiple regression analysis between total organic halide components and experimentally measured water toxicities (iii and iv). Educational components of the project will provide opportunities for undergraduate (e.g., Creative Inquiry Program at Clemson, UIUC WaterCamps program, the UIUC Global Safe Water Institute) and high school student research, including recruitment of underrepresented groups in scientific research.

por.por_cntn:
Given that almost half of the world’s population lives near 100 km of the world’s oceans, there has been a dramatic increase in global desalination capacity over the last decade. Nowadays, around 64% of desalination plants practice blending desalinated waters with single or multiple fresh waters obtained from other sources (e.g., treated surface waters or ground waters) as a low-cost method to meet drinking water demands. However, levels of bromide (Br-) and iodide (I-) in desalinated waters are generally high (e.g., Br- up to 600 μg/L reported for desalinated seawaters vs median Br- level in US surface waters of 100 μg/L). Blending desalinated waters (enriched in Br- and I-) with other treated source waters (dissolved organic carbon (DOC) sources) can cause the formation of different brominated, iodinated, and bromo/iodo-mixed disinfection byproducts (DBPs), if either chlorine or chloramine is used as post-disinfectants. Brominated and iodinated DBPs are more toxic than their chlorinated analogues. However, very little is known regarding how blending may increase the formation of brominated/iodinated DBPs and thereby increase the potential toxicity of the produced water. Therefore, we investigated the formation and speciation of brominated/iodinated DBPs (regulated trihalomethanes (THMs) and haloacetic acids (HAAs), unregulated haloacetnonitriles (HANs), iodinated trihalomethanes (I-THMs) and haloacetaldehydes (HALs)) from waters of different origins (three types of raw surface waters, three types of treated surface waters, three types of algal organic matter (AOM), and five types of effluent organic matter (EfOM)) typically used for blending with desalinated water and the change in the cytotoxicity and genotoxicity of waters as a result of blending. Finally, innovative treatment technologies (silver impregnated activated carbon, and ion-exchange resins) for selective removal of bromide and iodide were explored.

During chlorination, the formation of THMs and HAAs increased as the specific UV absorbance at 254 nm (SUVA) of surface waters (raw and treated, SUVA ranging from 1.7 to 5.1) increased; however, there was no clear trend for HANs and HALs. Due to the narrow SUVA range of AOM and EfOM (ranging from 0.5 to 2.0), there was no clear trend between DBP formation and SUVA. The formation of I-THMs was <1.7 mg/L since most of initial I- was oxidized to iodate. Increasing initial Br- concentrations increased the formation of THMs and HANs, while concentrations of total organic halogen and HAA remained stable. On the contrary, total HAL concentrations decreased due to the instability of bromated HALs. Low SUVA source waters (AOM and EfOM) was much more favorable for iodine incorporation than surface waters where natural organic matter (NOM) predominates.

During chloramination, I-THMs were the major DBPs formed, while the formation of chlorinated/brominated DBPs was low due to limited free chlorine/bromine exposure. Short contact time (2 min) chlorination prior to chloramination process leading to the formation of halogenated intermediates favored I-THM formation, compared with chloramination process. Increasing chlorine contact time from 5 min to 24 h facilitated the conversion from iodide to iodate and thus I-THM formation decreased. Meanwhile, the formation of noniodinated THM4, HANs, and HALs increased.

When various types of source waters were blended with desalinated waters, the change in the cytotoxicity and genotoxicity of waters as a result of blending will be of great concern. In the presence of low concentration of iodide (40 µg/L), increasing the chlorine contact time increased the cytotoxicity and genotoxicity because brominated/chlorinated DBPs were the major DBPs formed. On the contrary, in the presence of high concentration of iodide (127 µg/L), increasing the chlorine contact time decreased the cyto-toxicity of treated waters, probably because chlorination enhanced the formation of non-toxic iodate, thereby diminishing the formation of highly toxic iodinated DBPs. Unknown total organic halogen showed a high correlation with measured cytotoxicity, which indicates the necessity and importance of the identification of unknown DBPs.

Removal of bromide and iodide was investigated by using silver impregnated activated carbon (SIACs), developing a novel AgCl-SPAC composite, and bromide-selective resins. Regardless of the preparation procedure, SIACs showed significantly Br- uptakes than the virgin ACs, which also reduced the formation of brominated THMs. The novel composite AgCl-SPAC exhibited fast removal kinetics of Br− and I− by AgCl-SPAC with equilibrium times at 150 s and <10 s, respectively (i.e., 2–3 orders of magnitudes faster than previously tested Ag-based composites). We also compared the performance of four different anion exchange resins, including two novel Br-selective resins, for the removal of Br-. The Br resin showed Br- removal efficiencies of 93.5±4.5% for the initial Br- concentration of 0.25 mg/L in the presence of competing anions. After Br- removal, the subsequent formation of brominated DBPs as well as total organic halogens (TOX) decreased by ~90% under the uniform formation conditions. These novel materials represent promising alternative approaches, to be integrated continuously or seasonally, for controlling the formation of brominated and/or iodinated DBPs at water treatment plants.
